textContent:
The moving parts (in plain English)

Strike price: The insured price (your ceiling for calls / floor for puts).

Expiration date: The policy end date; after this, your right disappears, the insurance expires.

Premium: The cost of your policy (your maximum possible loss as a buyer).

Contract size: 1 listed option typically controls 100 shares.

Example: Call (right to buy):

Strike $50, premium $2 per share. If stock rips to $60, you can still buy at $50. If stock stays ≤ $50, you let it expire. Max loss = $2 × 100 = $200 per contract.

Example: Put (right to sell):

Strike $50, premium $2 per share. If stock dumps to $40, you can sell at $50. If stock stays ≥ $50, you let it expire. Max loss = $200 per contract.

questions.question: True/False - If you buy a Call, you are required to purchase the stock at the strike price before the option expires?

options.feedback: As an Option buyer, you have the "option" to exercise the Call or not. Allowing it to expire worthless is very common.

questions.question:
What is the price you will pay to buy this call?

Strike - $50

Premium - $2

Expiration Date - 12/19/2025

options.feedback: This is the strike price of the Option contract which is the negotiated price between you and the seller for the underlying stock.
Close! But incorrect. While this IS the premium price, this is the "per-share" premium price and needs to be multiplied by the number of shares in the contract, which is almost always 100.
Insurance always costs something. No one will insure you for free.

questions.question: True/False - Purchasing an option contract is an agreement between you and another trader?

options.feedback: While always anonymous, your transaction is between yourself and another trader in the market, not a public "float" as it is in stock transactions.
